facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1970 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1970. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 13th October 1970 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1112 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 13th October, 1970 of the Bombay High Court at Bombay in Criminal Appeal No. 1112 of 1970,.

facts.text: Appellant is a Sub Inspector in the Railway Protection Force.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge of Greater Bombay tried the appellant a Sub Inspector in the Railway Production Force,

facts.text: Appellant and three other members tried on charges under Section 120B and 161 IPC and Sections 5(1)(d) and 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: together with three other members of the Force, serving under him, on charges for offences punishable under Section 120B and 161 Indian Penal Code and Sections 5 1  d  and 5  2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: Appellant and Rakshaks conspired to extort money from Shivaji Ogale, P.W.2, a merchant.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the appellant and the Rakshaks serving under him at Bhusaval Central Railway Station had conspired to, extort money from Shivaji Ogale, P.W.2, a merchant owning property

facts.text: Shivaji Ogale owns property and goods estimated at Rs. 1,50,000/- and pays Income-tax and Sales-tax.

anchor.surface_text: owning property and goods estimated by him at Rs. 1,50,000/-, and paying Income-tax and Salestax.

facts.text: Incident occurred about 4 p.m. on 17-1-1968 at Bhusaval Central Railway Station goods yard.

anchor.surface_text: Shivaji was himself said to be present at the scene at that time which was about 4 p.m. on 17-1-1968.

facts.text: Appellant stopped Shivaji from removing goods on ground that truck was parked at wrong place.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is alleged to have stopped Shivaji from removing his goods from the goods yard on the ground that the truck brought by him was parked at the wrong place.

facts.text: Appellant and Rakshaks threatened truck driver Kalandar Khan, P.W.3, handcuffed him, tied with rope, took to appellant's office.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, with the help of his Rakshaks, was said to have threatened Kalandar Khan, P.W. 3, the driver of the truck, and to have actually handcuffed him and tied him with a rope and taken him to the appellants office

facts.text: Appellant and Hari Rachu demanded Rs. 200/- as bribe for releasing truck driver.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his co-accused, Hari Rachu, were alleged to have demanded Rs. 200/- as bribe for releasing the truck driver without whom the truck could not be driven away.

facts.text: Shivaji begged appellant to release driver; demand reduced to Rs. 100/-

anchor.surface_text: The vexed Shivaji is said to have fallen at the feet of the appellant and to have begged him to release his driver. The appellant then reduced his demand to Rs. 100/-.

facts.text: Shivaji sent son Sarjearao, P.W.4, to shop to get Rs. 100/- in Rs. 10/- notes within half an hour; handed over to appellant and Hari Rachu.

anchor.surface_text: Shivaji is said to have sent his son Sarjearao, P.W. 4, to his shop to get Rs. 100/- which were brought in Rs. 10/- notes within half an hour and handed over to the extortionists.

facts.text: After payment, appellant released driver and allowed truck to go.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is said to have released the driver and allowed the truck to go away after this payment had been actually made.

facts.text: Complaint lodged at 8 a.m. on 18-1-1968 in complaint book Ex.10.

anchor.surface_text: The complaint mentioned above was lodged at about 8 a.m. on 18-1-1968 after an imposition of Rs. 7.10 as wharfage charges

facts.text: Shivaji told Chief Goods Clerk, P.W.8, about incident around 6 p.m. on 17-1-1968.

anchor.surface_text: Shivaji had also stated that he had related everything to the Chief Goods Clerk of Bhusaval, P.W. 8, about 6 p.m. on 17-1- 1968.

facts.text: Wharfage charges of Rs. 7.10 imposed as goods could not be removed on 17-1-1968 due to interruption by appellant and associates.

anchor.surface_text: after an imposition of Rs. 7.10 as wharfage charges as all the goods could not be removed on 17-1-1968 presumably because of the interruption caused by the action of the appellant and his asso- ciates.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted appellant under Sections 120B, 161 r/w 34 IPC, 5(1)(d) and 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act; sentenced to 2 years RI and fine Rs.300/-, concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge... had convicted the appellant under Section 120B as well as Section 161 read with Section 34 I.P.C. and also under Section 5 1  d  and Sec. 5  2  of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentenced him to two years rigorous imprisonment

facts.text: Appellant and other convicts appealed to Bombay High Court; appellant's appeal dismissed summarily.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as well as the other convicts had appealed to the High Court-of Bombay, The appellants appeal had been dismissed summarily.

facts.text: Kalandar Khan was actually arrested by appellant, as per Abdul Jabar P.W.10.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Jabars evidence... disclosed that Kalandar Khan was actually arrested by the appellant a fact denied and left unexplained by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant denied the arrest of Kalandar Khan.

anchor.surface_text: a fact denied and left unexplained by the appellant.

facts.text: Cash book entry of Rs.100/- bribe and Rs.7.10 wharfage on 17-1-1968, but made on 19-1-1968 or 18-1-1968, not relied upon.

anchor.surface_text: Another piece of corroborative evidence offered by the prosecution was the Pucca entry of a disbursement of Rs. 100/- as bribe and Rs. 7.10 as wharfage shown on 17-1-1968 in the cash book of Shivaji. But...

facts.text: Shivaji identified Hari Rachu at test identification parade as person receiving money, but at trial said paid to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Considerable stress is laid on the fact that Shivaji had pointed out, it a test identification parade, the accused No. 2, Hari Rachu, as the person to whom the money was paid, but, at the trial,

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal and confirms convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: We hereby dismiss this appeal and confirm the convictions and sentences passed against the appellant who.is on bail. Ile shall surrender forthwith and serve out the remaining period of his concurrent sentences.

facts.text: Shivaji Ogale is an old man of seventy.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently, Shivaji, P.W. 2, an old man of seventy, was very agitated by what had taken place.

facts.text: Members of Railway Protection Force are not Police Officers; appellant exceeded powers of arrest.

anchor.surface_text: It has been relied upon... that, under the provisions of the Railway Protection Force, the members of that Force are not Police Officers at all in the ordinary sense, and that the appellant had apparently exceeded his powers of arrest.
under Section 120B and 161 Indian Penal Code and Sections 5 1  d  and 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution case against the appellant was established beyond reasonable doubt for offences under Section 120B IPC, Section 161 read with Section 34 IPC, Section 5(1)(d) and Section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act?

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge, after a very through and careful assessment of he whole evidence in the case, had come to the conclusion that the prosecution case against the appellant was established beyond reasonable doubt. He had convicted the appellant under Section 120B as well as Section 161 read with Section 34 I.P.C.

issues.text: Whether this Court should interfere with the concurrent findings of fact of the trial court and High Court?

anchor.surface_text: the general rule laid down by this Court in numerous cases, such as B. C. Goswami v. Delhi Administration, that this Court will not interfere with concurrent findings of fact except under very exceptional circumstances.

issues.text: Whether the appellant had justifiable grounds to arrest Kalandar Khan under Section 12 of the Railway Protection Force Act?

anchor.surface_text: under Section 12, vested in Superior Officers of the Force, are laid down in the following terms Power to arrest without warrant. ... It has not been shown to us what justifiable ground the appellant had to arrest or cause the arrest of Kalandar Khan.

issues.text: Whether the discrepancy in Shivaji's identification of the recipient of the bribe at the test identification parade and at trial is fatal to the prosecution case?

holdings.text: The prosecution case against the appellant was established beyond reasonable doubt for offences under Section 120B IPC, Section 161 read with Section 34 IPC, Section 5(1)(d) and Section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge, after a very through and careful assessment of he whole evidence in the case, had come to the conclusion that the prosecution case against the appellant was established beyond reasonable doubt. He had convicted the appellant under Section 120B as well as Section 161 read with Section 34 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court assessed evidence thoroughly and convicted; High Court affirmed; Supreme Court finds no reason to interfere after independent review.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not interfere with concurrent findings of fact of the trial court and High Court except under very exceptional circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: the general rule laid down by this Court in numerous cases, such as B. C. Goswami v. Delhi Administration, that this Court will not interfere with concurrent findings of fact except under very exceptional circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows established precedent; no exceptional circumstances present after review of evidence.

holdings.text: Appellant had no justifiable ground to arrest Kalandar Khan under Section 12 of the Railway Protection Force Act, indicating attempt to extort bribe.

anchor.surface_text: under Section 12, vested in Superior Officers of the Force, are laid down in the following terms Power to arrest without warrant. ... It has not been shown to us what justifiable ground the appellant had to arrest or cause the arrest of Kalandar Khan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence shown of offence relating to railway property or concealment; arrest corroborates prosecution's extortion claim.

holdings.text: Discrepancy in Shivaji's identification at test identification parade and trial is not fatal to prosecution case.

anchor.surface_text: Considerable stress is laid on the fact that Shivaji had pointed out, it a test identification parade, the accused No. 2, Hari Rachu, as the person to whom the money was paid, but, at the trial, he stated that it was paid to the appellant accused No. 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long time elapsed between incident and trial; possible honest lapse of memory regarding sequence of payment.

holdings.text: Testimony of Kalandar Khan (PW 3) is unreliable due to contradictions with prior statements.

anchor.surface_text: He was declared hostile by the prosecution. He was cross-examined about the statements made by him during investigation showing that he was arrested and that he actually saw the handing over of money as a bribe for his release.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradicts own investigation statements; no reason for investigating officer to falsely record.

holdings.text: High Courts should record brief reasons even when dismissing criminal appeals summarily on facts.

anchor.surface_text: we consider it very necessary for High Courts to at least record their reasons briefly even when they dismiss criminal appeal summarily on facts found.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary to disclose consideration of evidence and avoid difficulties in higher appeals; observed despite upholding findings.

holdings.text: False denial by appellant of Kalandar Khan's arrest indicates dishonesty and corroborates prosecution version.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had, no doubt, denied the arrest. This denial was clearly false in view of the statements of witnesses who included Abdul Jabar, P.W.10,
